items.content_html:
Description

Motivation

This came up in mdn/browser-compat-data#19681
items.title: Frames can't exist within a <body>

Description

correct the description and make the context consistent
items.title: correct the description and make the context consistent

items.content_html:
FF114 adds support for the Popover API behind a preference. This adds the Experimental features entry.

Other docs work can be tracked in #26694
items.title: FF114 Add Popover API to FF Experimental Features

items.content_html:
This updates the popover API "Web API" docs with some live examples. The examples are all very similar - they mirror for the button vs input elements.

Note that I did not update a live example for the event handler, or add to the show/hide/toggle methods. I could certainly do so if you think it useful? (mostly ran out of steam).

This is worth doing IMO because live examples are a very obvious up-front demo of browser support. I also found it useful because it wasn't obvious to me at first that if you declare an element as a popover when popover API is not supported that div displays its content. A bit ugly.

@chrisdavidmills YOu'd be the right person to look at this. I'm very pleased you already documented this - the "Using guide" is really good.

Related docs work in #26694
items.title: Popover API - add live examples for Web API

items.content_html:
Description

I clarified the two sentences under the Notifications heading on the 'How to make PWAs re-engageable using Notifications and Push' article.

Motivation

I think the reword helps readers understand the intro to this section of the article a bit better. The main thing that confused me was the usage of 'them' at the end of the first sentence on line 20, but I modified the sentences around it in order to fully clarify.

Additional details

None

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Reword the Notifications section of the PWA 'Notifications and Push' article

items.content_html:
Description

Explicitly say that Firefox and Chrome use different serialization algorithms to pass return value of scripting.executeScript() WebExtensions method.

Motivation

Despite current description of script result has a link to the Chrome incompatibilities page, wording is confusing. The phrase does not suggest that another serialization method is implemented in Chrome. Explicit mention of JSON serialization along with structured clone should warn readers about corner cases.
items.title: scripting.executeScript: result serialization incompatibility

items.content_html:
Description

Fixes #26852.
This PR removes the mentions of Modernizr on the feature detection page.

Motivation

Modernizn's last news on their website was in 2017. Their last release on github was in Feb 2022. It feels to me like the development has slowed down considerably and I'm not sure MDN should continue talking about it on the feature detection article.

I expect MDN not to mention frameworks or libraries that are bound to become outdated fairly fast in our fast moving world of web development.
The rest of the article is very good. I just think the section about modernizr should be deleted.

Additional details

N/A

Related issues and pull requests

#26852.
items.title: Remove mentions of Modernizr in feature detection page

items.content_html:
There is one instance of go used as a language for code blocks. We do not (yet) support Go in Prism syntax highlighting. This of course raises a build error which we can resolve in this PR.

```go
func (svg *SVG) TheOnlyGoExample(
```

Instead of adding Go as a supported language for this one example, I propose to rewrite the example in plain JS which translates better to our usual conventions for examples.

Improvements / suggestions on the example are welcome.
items.title: chore: remove Golang example, add JS variant instead

items.content_html:
This PR adds a How-to for triggering the installation process from inside the app, using beforeinstallprompt. Having dug into this event a bit for #26828 I thought I might as well write the how-to up.

A couple of questions:

  • arguably we might want to make this "how to customize app install" and include stuff about customizing the prompt itself. But I didn't do that partly because these seem like quite distinct things to want to do, and partly because this bit is done and we can merge it, and the other stuff isn't.
  • I wrote a mini-PWA to test this out. It made me wonder if we should have mini-examples in mdn/pwa-examples for how-to guides. It's nice having working code to back this stuff up.
  • I wasn't sure about appinstalled, or if there is more to be said there. I was a bit surprised actually that although I call preventDefault() I still get the icon in the URL bar.
items.title: PWA How-to: trigger installation from a PWA

items.content_html:
The current page for decodeAudioData() is bad at explaining the newer promise-based syntax, and it is the newer, better way to go. These edits update the page to reflect the newer reality of promises and async/await.
I have also created an updated example web page for webaudio-examples. That PR is here: mdn/webaudio-examples#104
I am a bit worried by a mistake I made in my last PR to this repo: I never created a separate branch, I committed to my main branch. Now those commits are in this new dAD branch and I don't know if that screws up your merge. Let me know if there is anything I should do about that and if I need to create a new PR as a result.
items.title: New and improved promise-based syntax examples and other edits

items.content_html:
Description

The direction property, while not deprecated, is heavily discouraged by the CSS Spec authors. This PR adds this warning to the direction property page.

Motivation

As MDN is often the first stop for developers exploring CSS properties, this warning should be present here. A similar warning is posted about unicode-bidi.

Additional details

from https://drafts.csswg.org/css-writing-modes-3/#direction

Because HTML UAs can turn off CSS styling, we recommend HTML authors to use the HTML dir attribute and element to ensure correct bidirectional layout in the absence of a style sheet. Authors should not use direction in HTML documents.

CSS WG discussion on the topic: w3c/csswg-drafts#2091

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Add warning to CSS direction page

items.content_html:
The pages for BeforeInstallPromptEvent are incomplete and wrong in various ways:

  • pages for all members except prompt() are missing
  • in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/BeforeInstallPromptEvent the summary for userChoice incorrectly says it resolves to a string
  • in https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/BeforeInstallPromptEvent/prompt it is incorrectly claimed that the result object has a userChoice member, and that its platform member reflects the platform property (there isn't a platform property, it's platforms).
  • examples are a bit odd, as in not the kind of thing you would ever do with this event.

Since AFAICT it's non-standard, I've documented with what I could find in Chrome (from testing and looking at https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/renderer/modules/app_banner/before_install_prompt_event.idl) rather than what's in https://wicg.github.io/manifest-incubations/#beforeinstallpromptevent-interface . If we think this is a good plan I'll need to update BCD a bit as well.

I wasn't really sure what BeforeInstallPromptEvent.platforms is. I'm also not sure my code samples are that good.
items.title: Update beforeinstallpromptevent

items.content_html:
Description

  • Change /docs/ links to /en-US/docs/
  • Add missing {{WebExtAPIRef in declarativenetrequest/index.md

Motivation

There is a missing {{WebExtAPIRef in the DNR article. I might have overlooked it before because the bot was spitting out tons of "useless" warnings about non-resolvable URLs. I fixed it by replacing /docs/ with /en-US/docs/, and then /en-US/en-US/docs/ with /en-US/docs/.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

This is a follow-up to #26793
items.title: DNR docs: replace /docs with /en-US/docs + fix missing WebExtAPIRef

items.content_html:
Firefox is the only widely used engine not supporting -webkit-text-security, and it seems to be in use in the wild to conceal password fields, as per this webcompat.com report. Chrome Platform Status implies that its usage is low (~0.3%), but slowly growing.

Description

whatwg/compat#240

Motivation

Fixed in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1826629 and released in Firefox 114.

Additional details

  • https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/c5031904ac17
  • https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/0b42da869302
items.title: Add the support for -webkit-text-security in Release 114

items.content_html:
Length values are not always absolute. For example we can use 2em for height property as a length value but it is not absolute. I corrected this in the Values section.

Description

Motivation

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: Correct length values description
